member.name: T:csscript.PrecompilationContext
member.summary:
This class is a container for information related to the script precompilation.
It is used to pass an input information from the script engine to the precompiler instance as well as to pass back to the script engine some output information (e.g. added referenced assemblies) .

member.name: F:csscript.PrecompilationContext.NewReferences
member.summary:
Collection of the referenced assemblies to be added to the process script referenced assemblies.
You may want to add new items to the referenced assemblies because of the precompilation logic (e.g. some code using assemblies not referenced by the primary script is injected in the script).

member.name: F:csscript.PrecompilationContext.NewDependencies
member.summary:
Collection of the new dependency items (files).
Dependency files are checked before the script execution in order to understand if the script should be recompiled or it can be loaded from the cache. If any of the dependency files is changed since the last script execution the script engine will recompile the script. In the simple execution scenarios the script file is a dependency file.

member.name: F:csscript.PrecompilationContext.NewSearchDirs
member.summary:
Collection of the assembly and script probing directories to be added to the process search directories.
You may want to add new items to the process search directories because of the precompilation logic.

member.name: F:csscript.PrecompilationContext.SearchDirs
member.summary: Collection of the process assembly and script probing directories.

member.name: P:csscript.Settings.CleanupShellCommand
member.summary:
Command to be executed to perform custom cleanup. If this value is empty automatic cleanup of all temporary files will occurs after the script execution. This implies that the script has to be executed in the separate AppDomain and some performance penalty will be incurred.
Setting this value to the command for custom cleanup application (e.g. csc.exe cleanTemp.cs) will force the script engine to execute script in the 'current' AppDomain what will improve performance.

member.name: P:csscript.Settings.DoCleanupAfterNumberOfRuns
member.summary: This value indicates frequency of the custom cleanup operation. It has affect only if CleanupShellCommand is not empty.

member.name: P:csscript.Settings.UseAlternativeCompiler
member.summary: Location of alternative code provider assembly. If set it forces script engine to use an alternative code compiler.

member.name: P:csscript.Settings.UsePostProcessor
member.summary: Location of PostProcessor assembly. If set it forces script engine to pass compiled script through PostProcessor before the execution.

member.name: P:csscript.Settings.DefaultApartmentState
member.summary: DefaultApartmentState is an ApartmemntState, which will be used at run-time if none specified in the code with COM threading model attributes.

member.name: P:csscript.Settings.DefaultArguments
member.summary: Default command-line arguments. For example if "/dbg" is specified all scripts will be compiled in debug mode regardless if the user specified "/dbg" when a particular script is launched.

member.name: P:csscript.Settings.OpenEndDirectiveSyntax
member.summary: Enables omitting closing character (";") for CS-Script directives (e.g. "//css_ref System.Xml.dll" instead of "//css_ref System.Xml.dll;").

member.name: P:csscript.Settings.TargetFramework
member.summary: Specifies the .NET Framework version that the script is compiled against. This option can have the following values: v2.0 v3.0 v3.5 v4.0

member.name: P:csscript.Settings.CompilerFramework
member.summary: Specifies the .NET Framework version that the script is compiled against. This option can have the following values: v2.0 v3.0 v3.5 v4.0

member.name: P:csscript.Settings.DefaultRefAssemblies
member.summary: List of assembly names to be automatically referenced by the scripst. The items must be separated by coma or semicolon. Specifying .dll extension (e.g. System.Core.dll) is optional. Assembly can contain expandable environment variables.

member.name: P:csscript.Settings.SearchDirs
member.summary: List of directories to be used to search (probing) for referenced assemblies and script files. This setting is similar to the system environment variable PATH.

member.name: P:csscript.Settings.HideAutoGeneratedFiles
member.summary: The value, which indicates if auto-generated files (if any) should should be hidden in the temporary directory.

member.name: P:csscript.Settings.Precompiler
member.summary: Path to the precompiller script/assembly (see documentation for details). You can specify multiple recompiles separating them by semicolon.

member.name: P:csscript.Settings.ReportDetailedErrorInfo
member.summary: Boolean flag that indicates how much error details to be reported should error occur. false - Top level exception will be reported true - Whole exception stack will be reported

member.name: P:csscript.Settings.OptimisticConcurrencyModel
member.summary:
Gets or sets a value indicating whether Optimistic Concurrency model should be used when executing scripts from the host application. If set to true the script loading (not the execution) is globally thread-safe. If set to false the script loading is thread-safe only among loading operations for the same script file.
The default value is true.
member.value: true if Optimistic Concurrency model otherwise, false.

member.name: P:csscript.Settings.HideCompilerWarnings
member.summary: Boolean flag that indicates if compiler warnings should be included in script compilation output. false - warnings will be displayed true - warnings will not be displayed

member.name: P:csscript.Settings.InMemoryAsssembly
member.summary: Boolean flag that indicates the script assembly is to be loaded by CLR as an in-memory byte stream instead of the file. This setting can be useful when you need to prevent script assembly (compiled script) from locking by CLR during the execution. false - script assembly will be loaded as a file. It is an equivalent of Assembly.LoadFrom(string assemblyFile). true - script assembly will be loaded as a file. It is an equivalent of Assembly.Load(byte[] rawAssembly)

member.name: T:csscript.Settings.HideOptions
member.summary: Enum for possible hide auto-generated files scenarios Note: when HideAll is used it is responsibility of the pre/post script to implement actual hiding.

member.name: F:csscript.Settings.HideOptions.DoNotHide
member.summary: Do not hide auto-generated files.

member.name: F:csscript.Settings.HideOptions.HideMostFiles
member.summary: Hide the most of the auto-generated (cache and "imported") files.

member.name: F:csscript.Settings.HideOptions.HideAll
member.summary: Hide all auto-generated files including the files generated by pre/post scripts.

member.name: M:csscript.Utils.AddCompilerOptions(System.CodeDom.Compiler.CompilerParameters,System.String)
member.summary: Adds compiler options to the CompilerParameters in a manner that it does separate every option by the space character

member.name: M:csscript.CSSUtils.ParseAppArgs(System.String[],csscript.IScriptExecutor)
member.summary: Parses application (script engine) arguments.
member.param: Arguments
Script executor instance
member.returns: Index of the first script argument.

member.name: T:csscript.MetaDataItems
member.summary:
The MetaDataItems class contains information about script dependencies (referenced local assemblies and imported scripts) and compiler options. This information is required when scripts are executed in a 'cached' mode (/c switch). On the base of this information the script engine will compile new version of .compiled assembly if any of it's dependencies is changed. This is required even for referenced local assemblies as it is possible that they are a strongly named assemblies (recompiling is required for any compiled client of the strongly named assembly in case this assembly is changed).
The perfect place to store the dependencies info (custom meta data) is the assembly resources. However if we do so such assemblies would have to be loaded in order to read their resources. It is not acceptable as after loading assembly cannot be unloaded. Also assembly loading can significantly compromise performance.
That is why custom meta data is just physically appended to the file. This is a valid approach because such assembly is not to be distributed anywhere but to stay always on the PC and play the role of the temporary data for the script engine.
Note: A .dll assembly is always compiled and linked in a normal way without any custom meta data attached.

member.name: M:CSScriptLibrary.CSScript.#ctor
member.summary: Default constructor

member.name: M:CSScriptLibrary.CSScript.GetScriptName(System.Reflection.Assembly)
member.summary:
Determines whether the specified assembly is a script assembly (compiled script) and returns full path of the script file used to compile the assembly. The analysis is based on the fact that script assembly (in hosing scenarios) is always stamped with , which contains name of the script file the assembly was compiled from.
The format of the description
member.param: The assembly.
member.returns: Script file path if the specified assembly is a script assembly otherwise null.

member.name: M:CSScriptLibrary.CSScript.DefaultPrint(System.String)
member.summary: Default implementation of displaying application messages.

member.name: F:CSScriptLibrary.CSScript.CacheEnabled
member.summary: Controls if ScriptCache should be used when script file loading is requested (CSScript.Load(...)). If set to true and the script file was previously compiled and already loaded the script engine will use that compiled script from the cache instead of compiling it again. Note the script cache is always maintained by the script engine. The CacheEnabled property only indicates if the cached script should be used or not when CSScript.Load(...) method is called.

member.name: M:CSScriptLibrary.CSScript.GetCachedScriptAssembly(System.String)
member.summary: Returns cached script assembly matching the scrpt file name.
member.param: Pull path of the script file.
member.returns: Assembly loaded int the current AppDomain. Returns null if the loaded script cannot be found.

member.name: P:CSScriptLibrary.CSScript.Rethrow
member.summary: Force caught exceptions to be re-thrown.

member.name: P:CSScriptLibrary.CSScript.AssemblyResolvingEnabled
member.summary:
Enables automatic resolving of unsuccessful assembly probing on the base of the Settings.SearchDirs. Default value is true.
CLR does assembly probing only in GAC and in the local (with respect to the application) directories. CS-Script however allows you to specify extra directory(es) for assembly probing by setting enabling CS-Script assembly resolving through setting the AssemblyResolvingEnabled to true and changing the Settings.SearchDirs appropriately.

member.name: P:CSScriptLibrary.CSScript.ShareHostRefAssemblies
member.summary:
Gets or sets the assembly sharing mode. If set to true all assemblies (including the host assembly itself) currently loaded to the host application AppDomain are automatically available/accessible from the script code. Default value is true.
Sharing the same assembly set between the host application and the script require AssemblyResolvingEnabled to be enabled. Whenever SharesHostRefAssemblies is changed to true it automatically sets AssemblyResolvingEnabled to true as well.

member.name: P:CSScriptLibrary.CSScript.EvalNamespaces
member.summary:
Sets the ;-delimited string containing namespaces to be used by the C# expressions being compiled with and .
The default value is "System;System.IO;System.Diagnostics;System.Collections.Generic;System.Threading"
member.para: The following is a typical example of BuildEval usage:

member.name: M:csscript.CSSEnvironment.SaveAsTempScript(System.String)
member.summary: Saves code to the script file in the dedicated CS-Script temporary files location. You do not have to delete the script file after the execution. It will be deleted as part of the periodical automatic CS-Script maintenance.
member.param: The script file content.
member.returns: Name of the created temporary script file.

member.name: M:csscript.CSSEnvironment.GetTempScriptName
member.summary: Generates the script file path in the dedicated CS-Script temporary files location. You do not have to delete such file after the execution. It will be deleted as part of the periodical automatic CS-Script maintenance.
member.returns: Name of the temporary script file.

member.summary: Sets the location for the CS-Script temporary files directory.
member.param: The path for the temporary directory.

member.name: P:csscript.CSSEnvironment.ScriptFile
member.summary: The full name of the script file being executed.

member.name: P:csscript.CSSEnvironment.PrimaryScriptFile
member.summary: The full name of the primary script file being executed. Usually it is the same file as ScriptFile. However these fields are different if analysed from the pre/post-script.

member.name: T:csscript.AppInfo
member.summary: Repository for application specific data

member.name: T:CSScriptLibrary.FastInvokeDelegate
member.summary:
Delegate which is used as a return type for AsmHelper.GetMethodInvoker().
AsmHelper.GetMethodInvoker() allows obtaining dynamic method delegate emitted on the base of the MethodInfo (from the compiled script type).
member.param: Instance of the type which method is to be invoked.
Optional method parameters.

member.name: T:CSScriptLibrary.MethodDelegate
member.summary:
Delegate which is used as a return type for AsmHelper.GetMethodInvoker().
AsmHelper.GetStaticMethod() and AsmHelper.GetMethod() allow obtaining dynamic method delegate emitted on the base of the MethodInfo (from the compiled script type).
member.param: Optional method parameters.

member.name: T:CSScriptLibrary.AsmHelper
member.summary: Helper class to simplify working with dynamically loaded assemblies.

member.name: M:CSScriptLibrary.AsmHelper.#ctor(System.Reflection.Assembly)
member.summary: Creates an instance of AsmHelper for working with assembly dynamically loaded to current AppDomain. Calling "Dispose" is optional for "current AppDomain"scenario as no new AppDomain will be ever created.
member.param: Assembly object.

member.name: M:CSScriptLibrary.AsmHelper.#ctor(System.String,System.String,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Creates an instance of AsmHelper for working with assembly dynamically loaded to non-current AppDomain. This method initialises instance and creates new ('remote') AppDomain with 'domainName' name. New AppDomain is automatically unloaded as result of "disposable" behaviour of AsmHelper.
member.param: File name of the assembly to be loaded.
Name of the domain to be created.
'true' if assembly file should be deleted when new AppDomain is unloaded; otherwise, 'false'.

member.name: M:CSScriptLibrary.AsmHelper.Invoke(System.String,System.Object[])
member.summary: Executes static method of the underlying assembly.
member.param: 'Method' name including 'Type' name (e.g. MyType.DoJob). It is allowed to use wild card character to indicate that the Type name of the method is irrelevant (e.g. "*.Method").
List of 'Method' arguments.
member.returns: Returns object of the same type as 'Method' return type.

member.name: M:CSScriptLibrary.AsmHelper.InvokeInst(System.Object,System.String,System.Object[])
member.summary: Executes an instance method of the underlying assembly.
member.param: Instance of the object whose method is to be invoked.
'Method' name (excluding 'Type' name). It is allowed to use wild card character to indicate that the Type name of the method is irrelevant (e.g. "*.Method" or even "*.*").
List of 'Method' arguments.
member.returns: Returns object of the same type as 'Method' return type.

member.name: M:CSScriptLibrary.AsmHelper.TryCreateObject(System.String)
member.summary: Attempts to create instance of a class from underlying assembly.
member.param:
The 'Type' full name of the type to create. (see Assembly.CreateInstance()).
You can use wild card meaning the first type found. However only full wild card "*" is supported.
member.returns: Instance of the 'Type'. Returns null if the instance cannot be created.

member.name: M:CSScriptLibrary.AsmHelper.CreateObject(System.String)
member.summary: Creates instance of a class from underlying assembly.
member.param: The 'Type' full name of the type to create. (see Assembly.CreateInstance()). You can use wild card meaning the first type found. However only full wild card "*" is supported.
member.returns: Instance of the 'Type'. Throws an ApplicationException if the instance cannot be created.

member.name: M:CSScriptLibrary.AsmHelper.Unload
member.summary: Unloads 'remote' AppDomain if it was created.

member.name: M:CSScriptLibrary.AsmHelper.Dispose
member.summary: Implementation of IDisposable.Dispose(). Disposes allocated exetrnal resources if any. Call this method to unload non-current AppDomain (if it was created).

member.name: M:CSScriptLibrary.AsmHelper.Dispose(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Actual implementation of IDisposable.Dispose()
member.param: 'false' if the method has been called by the runtime from inside the finalizer ; otherwise, 'true'.

member.name: M:CSScriptLibrary.AsmHelper.Finalize
member.summary: Finalizer

member.name: P:CSScriptLibrary.AsmHelper.ScriptExecutionDomain
member.summary: Instance of the AppDomain, which is used to execute the script.

member.name: P:CSScriptLibrary.AsmHelper.RemoteObject
member.summary:
Reference to the "worker" object created in the remote AppDomain. This property is null unless was instantiated for the remote execution scenario.
This property can be useful when you need to access the remote object in order to manage the "life time" of the AsmHelper in Remoting and WCF scenarios.

example.code: var scriptHelper = new AsmHelper(scriptAsmFile, null, true); scriptHelper.RemoteObject.ExtendLifeFromMinutes(30);

member.name: P:CSScriptLibrary.AsmHelper.CachingEnabled
member.summary:
Flag that indicates if method caching is enabled. It is set to true by default.
When caching is enabled AsmHelper generates (emits) extremely fast delegates for the methods being invoked. If AsmHelper is in cache mode it performs more than twice faster. However generation of the delegate does take some time that is why you may consider switching caching off if the method is to be invoked only once.

member.name: P:CSScriptLibrary.AsmHelper.ProbingDirs
member.summary: Array of directories to be used for assembly probing.

member.name: T:CSScriptLibrary.IAsmBrowser
member.summary: Defines method for calling assembly methods and instantiating assembly types.

member.name: M:CSScriptLibrary.AsmBrowser.CreateInstance(System.String)
member.summary: Creates instance of a Type from underying assembly.
member.param: Name of the type to be instantiated. Allows wild card character (e.g. *.MyClass can be used to instantiate MyNamespace.MyClass).

member.name: T:CSScriptLibrary.FastInvoker
member.summary:
Class which is capable of emitting the dynamic method delegate based on the MethodInfo. Such delegate is extremely fast and it can demonstrate up to 100 times better performance comparing to the pure Reflection method invokation (MethodInfo.Invoke()).
Based on http://www.codeproject.com/KB/cs/FastInvokerWrapper.aspx

member.name: F:CSScriptLibrary.FastInvoker.info
member.summary: MethodInfo instance which was used to generate dynamic method delegate.

member.name: M:CSScriptLibrary.FastInvoker.#ctor(System.Reflection.MethodInfo)
member.summary: Constructor
member.param: MethodInfo instance which is to be used to generate dynamic method delegate.

member.name: M:CSScriptLibrary.FastInvoker.Invoke(System.Object,System.Object[])
member.summary: Invokes dynamic method delegate generated from the MethodInfo object.
member.param: Instance of the type which method is to be invoked.
Optional method parameters.
member.returns: Invokes dynamic method delegate return value

member.name: M:CSScriptLibrary.FastInvoker.GetMethodInvoker
member.summary: Returns dynamic method delegate generated from the MethodInfo object.
